choices.text: Is formed after single meiotic division
Maximum in number in 5 month of the fetus

questions.text: Primary oocyte:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The number of oogonia reaches its maximum at 20th weekI(5th month) , numbering about 7 million. While the majority of the oogonia continue to divide, some enter into the prophase of the first meiotic division and are called primary oocytes. Option A-prmary occyte is formed after single mitotic division and not meiotic Option C is in prophase arrest (diplotene < dictyotene – which is name of arrested phase between prophase and metaphase) Option D BLASTOCYST is formed after fertilization at the time when implantation begains at day 5th

questions.text: True statement with regards to resumption of Meiosis I is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Resumed due to LH. Correct Response: Resumed due to LH (B) The resumption of Meiosis I in oocytes (egg cells) is primarily triggered by a surge in luteinizing hormone (LH). During the menstrual cycle, the LH surge occurs just before ovulation and causes the resumption of meiosis in the oocyte that was arrested at prophase I. This surge in LH is a key factor in initiating the completion of Meiosis I, leading to the formation of a secondary oocyte and the arrest at metaphase II, until fertilization occurs. Thus, LH is the primary hormone responsible for resuming Meiosis I. Incorrect Responses: A. It is not hormone dependent (A) This statement is incorrect because the resumption of Meiosis I in oocytes is highly hormone-dependent. The hormonal regulation, particularly the rise in LH and FSH, is essential for the resumption of meiosis. Without these hormones, oocytes would remain arrested in prophase I. Therefore, the statement that it is "not hormone dependent" is incorrect. C. Resumed due to FSH (C) While follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) plays a crucial role in the early stages of follicular development, it is LH that specifically triggers the resumption of Meiosis I in the oocyte. FSH works more on promoting the growth and maturation of the ovarian follicle, but it does not directly resume meiosis. Hence, FSH is not the hormone responsible for the resumption of Meiosis I, making this option incorrect. D. Resumed due to GnRH (D) Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) is important for stimulating the release of FSH and LH from the anterior pituitary, but it does not directly cause the resumption of Meiosis I. GnRH triggers the release of LH, and it is the LH surge that directly causes the resumption of meiosis in the oocyte.

questions.text: Primary oocyte is formed after:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mitotic division. Correct Response: Mitotic division (C) The primary oocyte is formed as a result of mitotic division of oogonia during fetal development. Oogonia are the germ cells in the ovaries that undergo several rounds of mitotic division to proliferate. Once they reach a certain stage of development, they enter meiosis but get arrested at prophase I, thus becoming primary oocytes. This arrest in meiosis occurs before the first meiotic division, and these primary oocytes will remain in this arrested state until puberty, when they resume meiosis. Therefore, the primary oocyte is formed after mitotic division. Incorrect Responses: A. 1st meiotic division (A) The first meiotic division does not result in the formation of a primary oocyte. The primary oocyte is formed earlier, during mitotic division of oogonia. After this division, the primary oocyte enters prophase I of meiosis, where it remains arrested until ovulation. Therefore, the first meiotic division occurs after the formation of the primary oocyte, making this option incorrect. B. 2nd meiotic division (B) The second meiotic division takes place after the primary oocyte has completed meiosis I. The oocyte completes meiosis I during ovulation, resulting in the formation of a secondary oocyte and the first polar body. The secondary oocyte is then arrested in metaphase II of meiosis, which will only be completed upon fertilization. The primary oocyte is formed before the second meiotic division, so this option is incorrect. D. None of the above (D) Since the primary oocyte is indeed formed after mitotic division of oogonia, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: 1 primary oocyte forms_____ number of ova:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1. Correct Response: 1 (A) Each primary oocyte undergoes meiosis to produce one mature ovum (egg). During the meiotic process, meiosis I results in the formation of a secondary oocyte and a polar body. The secondary oocyte continues through meiosis II but arrests in metaphase II until fertilization. Once fertilized, it completes meiosis II to produce one mature ovum and another polar body. Therefore, from one primary oocyte, only one viable ovum is produced, along with two non-functional polar bodies. This is why the correct answer is A. Incorrect Responses: B. 2 (B) Two viable ova are not produced from a single primary oocyte. While meiosis results in two cells, one is always a secondary oocyte and the other is a polar body, and the polar body does not contribute to the formation of a mature ovum. Thus, two viable eggs do not come from one primary oocyte, so this option is incorrect. C. 3 (C) In the process of oogenesis, three cells are produced, but only one of them becomes a viable ovum, and the other two are polar bodies. Therefore, three viable ova are not produced, making this option incorrect. D. 4 (D) Four cells are produced during oogenesis, but only one of them is a mature ovum, while the remaining three are polar bodies, which are non-functional. The number of viable ova from one primary oocyte is one, so four viable ova is not the correct outcome. This makes option D incorrect.

questions.text: In ovarian cycle increased levels of LH are due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In ovarian cycle- LH and FSH levels are dependent on levels of estrogen and progesterone Increased level of estrogen always causes inhibitory effect on FSH While effect on LH depends upon level of estrogen present ; if the estrogen level is less than it will have inhibitory effect on LH while increased level of Estrogen will have stimulatory effect on LH Likewise low doses of progesterone stimulates both LH & FSH While high levels inhibit both This phenomenon of negative and positive feedback is known as neuroendocrinal phenomenon

questions.text: In 40 days of menstrual cycle the ovulation occurs at:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 26th day. Correct Response: C. 26th day In a typical 40-day menstrual cycle, ovulation occurs approximately 14 days before the start of the next menstrual period. Since the cycle is 40 days long, ovulation would typically happen around day 26 of the cycle. This is because ovulation is determined by the length of the luteal phase, which remains relatively consistent at about 14 days, regardless of the overall cycle length. So, if the cycle is longer, ovulation will occur later, in this case, on the 26th day. Incorrect Responses: A. 14th day (A) Ovulation occurring on the 14th day is common for women with a 28-day menstrual cycle. However, in a 40-day cycle, ovulation would be expected later, around day 26, as the luteal phase length remains roughly constant at 14 days. So, ovulation on the 14th day does not apply to a 40-day cycle, making this option incorrect. B. 20th day (B) Ovulation on the 20th day would be too early for a 40-day cycle, as ovulation occurs closer to the 26th day. The timing of ovulation in a 40-day cycle typically aligns more with day 26, not day 20, which is why this option is incorrect. D. 30th day (D) Ovulation on the 30th day would be too late. Ovulation typically occurs about 14 days before the next period, which in a 40-day cycle would be around the 26th day, not the 30th. So, this option is also incorrect.

questions.text: The corpus luteum secretes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The corpus luteum secretes progesterone, the level of which starts rising. The hormone progesterone has two functions. In the first place, it stimulates the endometrium to undergo secretory hypertrophy, and secondly, it inhibits further production of LH by the anterior pituitary. Natural oestrogens are C18 steroids, the main source of which are the theca and granulosa cells of the Graafian follicles and corpus luteum, while the adrenal cortex is the secondary source of supply. Hence corpus luteum secretes both estrogen and progesterone

choices.text: The involution of corpus luteum causes estradiol and progesterone levels to fall dramatically
Estracdiol levels are not involved in the LH surge phenomenon
Estradiol inhibits the induction of the progesterone receptor in the endometrium

questions.text: Apoptosis can occur by change in hormone levels in the ovarian cycle. When there is no fertilization of the ovum, the endometrial cells die because:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Menstruation is brought about by the fall in the levels of oestrogen and progesterone following the degeneration of the corpus luteum. Ovulation occur due to peak in level of LH ( LH surge) n post ovulation level of LH starts declining due to inhibitory effect of progesterone on LH Increased level of estrogen causes stimulatory effect on LH hence plays an imp role in LH surge Progesterone induces secretory changes only if the endometrium is primed by oestrogen, which produces progesterone receptors in the endometrial cells So answer here is option A

questions.text: Maximum function of corpus luteum occurs:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 8-9 days after ovulation. Correct Response: D. 8-9 days after ovulation The maximum function of the corpus luteum occurs around 8-9 days after ovulation. During this period, the corpus luteum reaches its peak secretion of progesterone, which is essential for maintaining the uterine lining in preparation for a possible pregnancy. If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum begins to regress and its hormone production decreases. Incorrect Responses: A. At ovulation (A) Although the corpus luteum begins its formation immediately after ovulation, its maximum function (in terms of hormone production, primarily progesterone) is not reached at the time of ovulation. At ovulation, the dominant follicle ruptures, and ovulation occurs, but it takes a few days for the corpus luteum to mature and begin its full secretion of hormones. B. Before ovulation (B) The corpus luteum is not formed before ovulation. It is formed after the release of the egg during ovulation from the ruptured follicle. Therefore, the corpus luteum has no functional role before ovulation. C. 3 days after ovulation (C) While the corpus luteum starts producing hormones shortly after ovulation, it has not yet reached its maximum functional capacity at 3 days. The peak of progesterone secretion happens around 8-9 days after ovulation, not at 3 days.

choices.text: After biphasic rise in body temperature
After ripening of follicle by FSH

questions.text: Ovulation occurs
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The cyclical release of gonadotropins, FSH first and later LH which induces ovulation. Changes before ovulation : Increase in FSH occur in response to pulsatile increase in GnRh (low ) which eventually marks onset of follicular phase and further increases oestrogen and inhibin b, and selection of dominant follicle occurs, increase estrogen causes LH surge which causes ovulation FSH helps in final phase of breakdown of collagen during ovulation Levels of FSH and LH both increases before ovulation FSH peak causes small increase in progesterone, it begains 36 hrs before ovulation Oestrogen peak also occur 36 hrs before ovulation. Hence answer here is option C

questions.text: True about timing of LH surge:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Occurs 36 hours before ovulation. Correct Response: B. Occurs 36 hours before ovulation The LH surge (Luteinizing Hormone surge) is a key event in the menstrual cycle that triggers ovulation. It typically occurs approximately 36 hours before ovulation. This surge causes the final maturation of the egg and triggers its release from the ovary. The timing of the LH surge is critical for successful ovulation and fertility. Incorrect Responses: A. Occurs 12 hours before ovulation (A) While the LH surge is closely timed with ovulation, it does not occur as early as 12 hours before ovulation. It typically happens about 36 hours before ovulation, so this option is incorrect. C. Occurs 24 hours before ovulation (C) Although it is close, the LH surge does not occur exactly 24 hours before ovulation. The typical timing is around 36 hours, so this is an inaccurate estimate. D. Occurs 24 hours after ovulation (D) This statement is completely incorrect. The LH surge occurs before ovulation, not after. It triggers the release of the egg and is a key factor in the process of ovulation, so it cannot occur after the event.

questions.text: Which of the following is not related with menstral cycle:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Estrous cycle. Correct Response: C. Estrous cycle The estrous cycle is a reproductive cycle seen in many non-human mammals, in which animals go through periods of estrus or heat. This cycle is different from the menstrual cycle seen in humans, where menstruation (shedding of the endometrial lining) occurs if fertilization doesn't take place. In contrast, most animals with an estrous cycle reabsorb the endometrial lining rather than shedding it. Therefore, the estrous cycle is not directly related to the menstrual cycle in humans. Incorrect Responses: A. Hormonal changes (A) Hormonal changes are an essential component of the menstrual cycle. The fluctuations in levels of estrogen and progesterone control the various stages of the menstrual cycle, including the follicular phase, ovulation, luteal phase, and menstruation. Therefore, hormonal changes are very much related to the menstrual cycle. B. Vaginal cytology (B) Vaginal cytology involves the study of cells shed from the vaginal lining. In humans, this can be used to assess the phases of the menstrual cycle. For example, the appearance of epithelial cells varies during different phases of the cycle (follicular, ovulation, luteal phases). Therefore, vaginal cytology is related to the menstrual cycle. D. Endometrial sampling (D) Endometrial sampling involves collecting tissue from the lining of the uterus, often to assess its response to hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle. This is commonly used in clinical settings to assess the health of the endometrium and detect abnormalities. Therefore, endometrial sampling is related to the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: Naturally occurring estrogens are all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Estrogen are divided into two categories : Naturally occurring Synthetic Natural estrogen : Estrole- predominantly occurring in post menopausal phase, come for pheripheral conversion of androsteinedione Estradiole – synthesis occurs from theca cells, predominant in reproductive age group Estriole – predominant in pregnancy Synthetic Estrogen : Ethinyl estradiole Conjugated equine estrogen

questions.text: End product of progesterone metabolism found in urine is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Progestrone is metabolised and excreted in the urine as sodium pregnanediol 3-glucuronide and recovered as such for assay in the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle. It's level can be estimated by enzyme immunoessay, enzyme dipstick test are available now which can be used to d determine occurane of ovulation Daily production of progestrone in the luteal phase is 20–40 mg and daily urine excretion is 3–6 mg.

choices.text: Increased secretion of inhibin occurs in polycystic ovarian disease

questions.text: Following are the features of inhibin except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Inhibin is a nonsteroidal water-soluble protein (peptide) secreted by the Graafian follicle. Inhibin consists of two peptides, namely inhibin A (a-fraction) and inhibin B (b-fraction) Oestrogen is responsible for secretion of inhibin in the Graafian follicle, which in turn suppresses FSH but stimulates LH secretion. In polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD), there is an increased secretion of inhibin. This causes a low FSH but a high LH secretion by the anterior pituitary gland and is responsible for anovulation Normal level of 50 pg/mL drops to less than 15 pg/mL after menopause due to oestrogen deficiency. It is studied by ELISA test Hence answer here is option C

questions.text: The probable source of relaxin is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ovary. Correct Response: A. Ovary Relaxin is primarily produced by the ovaries, particularly by the corpus luteum during the menstrual cycle and pregnancy. Its main role is to relax the uterus and facilitate the expansion of the cervix during labor, as well as to promote the flexibility of the pelvic ligaments. This hormone is essential in preparing the body for childbirth. Therefore, the ovaries are the primary source of relaxin. Incorrect Responses: B. Adrenal cortex (B) While the adrenal cortex produces several hormones such as cortisol, aldosterone, and androgens, it does not produce relaxin. The adrenal glands are not involved in the production of relaxin, making this option incorrect. C. Bartholin's gland (C) Bartholin's glands are responsible for secreting mucus that lubricates the vaginal opening, but they do not produce relaxin. This option is not correct as Bartholin's glands do not play a role in the production of relaxin. D. Anterior pituitary (D) The anterior pituitary gland secretes hormones such as FSH, LH, and prolactin, but it does not produce relaxin. The anterior pituitary is not involved in the production of relaxin, making this option incorrect as well.

choices.text: It has got no blood supply
In the first half of the cycle, it has no steroidogenic function
Granulosa cells produce activin and inhibin
Estrogen stimulates the proliferation of granulose cells

questions.text: The following are related to granulose cells except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Granulosa cells : The lining of graffian follicle consists of two layers: (i) theca interna and (ii) granulosa layer. The granulosa layer itself is nonvascular and capillaries cannot be identified in it The formation of CallExner bodies is a distinct feature of granulosa cells and can be readily recognized in certain types of granulosa cell tumor The liquor folliculi is a clear fluid-containing protein which coagulates after formalin fixation. It is secreted by the granulosa cells and contains the ovarian hormone oestrogen.

choices.text: Estrogen continues to be produced by the luteinized theca cells
Luteolysis is due to estrogen, PGF2a and apoptosis
The peak steroid production is between 23 and 25th day

questions.text: The following are related to corpus luteum except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The corpus luteum reaches maximum maturity by the 22nd day of the normal cycle. After ovulation, the Graafian follicle cyst collapses and luteinization of the theca cells and the granulosa cells takes. Following ovulation, LH produces luteinization of the granulosa and the theca cells and initiates progesterone secretion. Prostaglandin F2α (PGF2α) is well established where it originates in the endometrium and traverses the utero-ovarian vasculature to reach the corpus luteum. luteolytic effect of PGF2α acting to decrease perfusion of the corpus luteum, and vascular regression is observed in the aging corpus luteum. Estrogen has a luteolytic effect. The direct luteolytic action of estrogen esult from estrogen-induced increases of PGF2a production by luteal cells. Regression of the corpus luteum is accompanied by programmed cell death, or apoptosis

questions.text: Granulosa cells produces estrogen with the help of the enzyme.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Aromatase. Correct Response: B. Aromatase Granulosa cells in the ovaries produce estrogen through the action of the enzyme aromatase. Aromatase is responsible for converting androgens (like testosterone) into estrogens (like estradiol) in the granulosa cells. This is an essential process in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and in the development of female secondary sexual characteristics. Aromatase plays a crucial role in estrogen biosynthesis, making this the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: A. Alkaline phosphatase (A) Alkaline phosphatase is an enzyme involved in various metabolic processes, including the breakdown of phosphate groups from molecules. However, it is not involved in estrogen production. Therefore, this option is incorrect. C. Acid phosphatase (C) Acid phosphatase is another enzyme that catalyzes the removal of phosphate groups from molecules, but it is primarily found in lysosomes and is not associated with estrogen production. Thus, this option is also incorrect. D. Glucuronidase (D) Glucuronidase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of glucuronic acid conjugates, which are often associated with the metabolism of various substances, including drugs. It does not play a role in the synthesis of estrogen.

questions.text: Peak level of plasma progesterone in the luteal phase:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 15 ng/ml. Correct Response: C. 15 ng/ml During the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle, which follows ovulation, the corpus luteum secretes progesterone to prepare the endometrium for possible implantation of a fertilized egg. The peak plasma progesterone levels during this phase generally reach around 15 ng/ml. This surge in progesterone is crucial for maintaining the uterine lining and supporting early pregnancy if fertilization occurs. Incorrect Responses: A. 5 ng/ml (A) A plasma progesterone level of 5 ng/ml is below the typical peak seen during the luteal phase. While progesterone levels can fluctuate, this value is too low to reflect the peak of progesterone in the luteal phase, making this option incorrect. B. 10 ng/ml (B) A level of 10 ng/ml is still below the peak progesterone levels observed during the luteal phase. Although progesterone levels do rise after ovulation, they typically do not reach their maximum at 10 ng/ml, making this option incorrect as well. D. 30 ng/ml (D) A plasma progesterone level of 30 ng/ml would be unusually high for the luteal phase. While levels can vary slightly, typical levels peak at around 15 ng/ml. A value as high as 30 ng/ml is not characteristic of the average luteal phase,

questions.text: The earliest morphological evidence of ovulation on endometrial biopsy is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day and persists until the onset of menstruation. The most characteristic signs of this phase are found in the glands. Their epithelial cells develop spherical translucent areas between the nuclei and the basement membrane which contain the precursors of the glandular secretion and which persist until about the 21st day of the cycle. This characteristic appearance is called subnuclear vacuolation and is presumptive evidence of progesterone activity and, therefore, of ovulation.

questions.text: Rise in body temperature after ovulation is due to :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Progesterone is known to exert a thermogenic effect on the body. Therefore, if the woman records her basal body temperature (BBT) daily on awakening in the morning and plots the readings graphically, the BBT chart will be biphasic in an ovulatory cycle. The day of temperature shift indicates the time of ovulation. Avoidance of intercourse during the fertile days can prevent an unwanted pregnancy

choices.text: LH surge is initiated due to sustained levels of 200 pg of estrogen for 48 hours
LH surge is maintained by esterogen and progestrone both

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Meiosis II is hormone dependent. Correct Response: D. Meiosis II is hormone dependent Meiosis II in females is not hormone-dependent. The completion of Meiosis II occurs after fertilization, where the oocyte completes the second meiotic division only if fertilization happens. Therefore, this statement is incorrect. The second meiotic division does not require the same hormonal regulation that Meiosis I does during oocyte maturation before ovulation. Incorrect Responses: A. LH surge is initiated due to sustained levels of 200 pg of estrogen for 48 hours (A) This statement is correct. The LH surge is indeed triggered by a sustained increase in estrogen levels (around 200 pg/ml) for about 48 hours. This is a well-known phenomenon in the hormonal regulation of ovulation, where a positive feedback loop of estrogen on the hypothalamus and pituitary gland leads to the LH surge, which induces ovulation. B. LH surge is maintained by estrogen and progesterone both (B) This statement is correct. The LH surge is not only triggered by high levels of estrogen, but it is also maintained through the combined effects of estrogen and progesterone. After the initial surge, progesterone levels increase, and together with estrogen, they continue to support the luteal phase and prevent further ovulations during the current cycle. C. Meiosis I is hormone dependent (C) This statement is correct. Meiosis I in the female oocyte is hormone-dependent, specifically under the control of FSH and LH. These hormones regulate the process of oocyte maturation and the completion of the first meiotic division, which is necessary for ovulation to occur.

choices.text: Prostaglandin released at the time of menstruation is PGE2
Zona basalis regenerates the endometrium during next cycle

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Prostaglandin released at the time of menstruation is PGE2. Correct Response: B. Prostaglandin released at the time of menstruation is PGE2 This statement is incorrect. The primary prostaglandin released during menstruation is PGE2 for causing uterine contractions, but PGF2? is typically considered to play the most significant role in menstruation and uterine contractions. Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF2?) is largely responsible for the painful uterine contractions that occur during menstruation. While PGE2 does play a role, PGF2? is the more dominant prostaglandin in the process of shedding the uterine lining and causing pain. Incorrect Responses: A. Menstrual blood is mainly arterial (A) This statement is correct. The blood lost during menstruation is primarily arterial, as it originates from the breakdown of blood vessels in the uterine lining. The menstrual flow typically consists of blood from small arteries in the endometrial lining, which are disrupted during menstruation. C. Zona basalis regenerates the endometrium during the next cycle (C) This statement is correct. The zona basalis, which is the deeper part of the endometrium, plays a critical role in regenerating the endometrial tissue during the next menstrual cycle. This regenerative capacity ensures that the functional layer of the endometrium, which is shed during menstruation, is replaced in preparation for potential pregnancy. D. Anovulatory cycles are painless (D) This statement is incorrect. Anovulatory cycles, or cycles in which ovulation does not occur, can still be painful. The lack of ovulation often leads to hormonal imbalances, and these cycles can be associated with symptoms such as abnormal bleeding, pain, and discomfort, similar to normal menstrual cycles.

questions.text: On examination of endometrial tissues obtained from a biopsy reveals simple columnar epithelium with no subnuclear vacuoles. The stroma is edematous and a tortous gland contains secretions. Thus findings are consistent with which stage of menstrual cycle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) As we know subnuclear vacuolation is the earliest histopathological change in secretory phase. These secretory vacuoles then move upwards towards the apex. Since subnuclear vacuolation is absent it is not early secretory phase. The edematous stroma and tortuous gland point towards mid secretory phase

questions.text: Pulsatile GnRH is used for managing :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Anovulatory infertility. Correct Response: D. Anovulatory infertility Pulsatile GnRH (Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone) is used in the treatment of anovulatory infertility. In women with anovulatory infertility, GnRH is administered in a pulsatile manner to mimic the natural secretion of GnRH, which stimulates the pituitary gland to release FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone) and LH (Luteinizing Hormone). This helps in the induction of ovulation, which is crucial for fertility. Pulsatile GnRH therapy is commonly used in women who have hypothalamic dysfunction, leading to anovulation. It helps to restore the normal cyclical release of gonadotropins, thus stimulating ovulation and improving fertility. Incorrect Responses: A. Precocious puberty (A) This statement is incorrect. In the case of precocious puberty, treatment typically involves the use of GnRH analogs (agonists) in a continuous form, not pulsatile. The goal of using continuous GnRH analogs is to suppress the early activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis and delay further sexual maturation until the appropriate age. Pulsatile GnRH is not used in this scenario. B. Fibroid (B) This statement is incorrect. Fibroids, or uterine leiomyomas, are not directly managed by pulsatile GnRH therapy. However, GnRH analogs (in a continuous form) can be used to reduce fibroid size by inducing a temporary menopause-like state, which lowers estrogen levels. Pulsatile GnRH is not indicated for fibroids treatment. C. DUB (Dysfunctional Uterine Bleeding) (C) This statement is incorrect. DUB (Dysfunctional Uterine Bleeding) is typically managed with hormonal treatments like oral contraceptives, progestins, or GnRH analogs, but pulsatile GnRH is not a first-line treatment. Pulsatile GnRH may be used in some cases of DUB related to anovulation, but it is not the primary treatment for this condition.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding estrogen except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Estrogen is produced by: Granulosa cells Theca cells form androgen which are converted to estrogen by enzyme aromatase under the influence of enzyme FSH (It is not secreted by Theca cells) Corpus luteum By peripheral conversion of androgens in adipose tissue.

choices.text: Enhanced by E and inhibited by P
Enhanced by P and inhibited by E

questions.text: Sensitivity of uterine musculature is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer C Enhanced by Estrogen and inhibited by Progesterone. Correct Response: C. Enhanced by Estrogen and inhibited by Progesterone This statement is correct. The sensitivity of uterine musculature (the myometrium) to stimuli, particularly oxytocin, is influenced by the balance of estrogen (E) and progesterone (P). Estrogen increases the sensitivity of the uterine muscle to oxytocin, promoting uterine contractions, which is important for labor and menstruation. On the other hand, progesterone has an inhibitory effect on the uterine muscles, reducing their responsiveness to stimuli and preventing contractions during pregnancy. Thus, estrogen enhances uterine sensitivity, while progesterone inhibits it. Incorrect Responses: A. Enhanced by Estrogen This statement is partially correct, but it is incomplete. While estrogen does enhance the sensitivity of the uterine musculature to stimuli like oxytocin, progesterone has the opposite effect by inhibiting uterine contractions. Therefore, this response overlooks the role of progesterone and does not fully explain the balance required for uterine function. B. Enhanced by Progesterone This statement is incorrect. While progesterone is important for maintaining pregnancy by reducing uterine contractions, it does not enhance the sensitivity of uterine musculature. In fact, progesterone decreases uterine muscle responsiveness, making this answer incorrect. D. Enhanced by Progesterone and inhibited by Estrogen This statement is incorrect. It mistakenly suggests that progesterone enhances uterine muscle sensitivity and that estrogen inhibits it. In reality, progesterone inhibits uterine muscle sensitivity, while estrogen enhances it, making this response reversed and incorrect.

questions.text: All of the following incrrease puberty except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) NPY is a major component of the neurobiological brake that holds the GnRH pulse generator in check during juvenile development Leptin exerts a permissive action on puberty by stimulating release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) in the hypothalamus. However, GnRH neurons lack leptin receptor (LepR), indicating that leptin must indirectly regulate these neurons. The Kiss1 gene produces kisspeptins that stimulate GnRH secretion.

questions.text: The decreasing order of potency of estrogen is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) E2-E1-E3. Explanation for Correct Answer (B): Estradiol (E2) is the most potent and biologically active form of estrogen. It plays the primary role in regulating the menstrual cycle and reproductive functions. Estrone (E1) is weaker in its effects compared to estradiol but still contributes to estrogenic activity. Estriol (E3) is the weakest form of estrogen and has the least potency among the three. Therefore, in decreasing order of potency, the sequence is E2 > E1 > E3. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. E3-E2-E1: This order is incorrect because estriol (E3) is the weakest estrogen, so it should not be placed first. The correct sequence should start with estradiol (E2), followed by estrone (E1), and then estriol (E3). C. E1-E2-E3: This order incorrectly places estrone (E1) before estradiol (E2). Since estradiol is the most potent form of estrogen, it should be placed at the beginning of the sequence, not estrone. D. E2-E3-E1: This option starts with estradiol (E2), which is correct, but then incorrectly places estriol (E3) before estrone (E1). Estrone (E1) has more potency than estriol (E3), so it should be listed after estradiol and before estriol.

choices.text: Thick mucus with back ground bacteria
A fern pattern characteristic of estrogen

questions.text: A sample of cervical mucus is taken on Day 12 of the menstrual cycle: The mucus is thin, clear, elastic. It it placed on a slide and allowed to air dry. When placed under microscope, what would you expect:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) On day 12, when cervical mucus is viewed under microscope, it shows a fern like pattern under the effect of estrogen. Secretion of cervical mucus is regulated by ovarian hormones. Estrogen stimulates the production of large amounts of thin, watery, alkaline, acellular cervical mucus with intense ferning, spinnbarkeit, and sperm receptivity. Progesterone inhibits the secretory activity of cervical epithelia and produces scanty, viscous, cellular mucus with low spinnbarkeit and absence of ferning, which is impenetrable by spermatozoa.

choices.text: Peripheral conversion to androgen precursors in the liver, gastro-intestinal tract and adipose tissue

questions.text: Major sources of androgen in females are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Corpus luteum. Explanation for Correct Answer (D): The corpus luteum primarily produces progesterone and a small amount of estrogen during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. However, it is not a major source of androgens. Androgen production in females is primarily through other sources such as the adrenals and ovaries. Therefore, the corpus luteum is not a significant contributor to androgen production in females. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Adrenals: The adrenal glands are a significant source of androgens in females. They produce adrenal androgens like dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione, which are important precursors for the production of estrogen and other hormones. B. Ovaries: The ovaries also produce androgens, mainly androstenedione and testosterone. These are important for the synthesis of estrogen in females, and thus the ovaries are a key source of androgens. C. Peripheral conversion to androgen precursors in the liver, gastro-intestinal tract, and adipose tissue: Peripheral tissues, including the liver, gastrointestinal tract, and adipose tissue, can convert estrogen precursors such as androstenedione into active androgens like testosterone. This peripheral conversion is an important source of androgens in females.

choices.text: Gender of an anatomically abnormal child
Malignant change at squamo columnar junction of cervix

questions.text: The maturation index on vaginal cytology is a diagnostic method for evaluating the:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The Maturation Index (MI) quantifies the estrogen status of the vaginal epithelium and related genital structures including the vulva, urethra and bladder. Three epithelial cell types, parabasal, intermediate and superficial, are used to evaluate vaginal estrogenization. A predominance of parabasal cells (the least mature type) and absence of superficial cells indicates a low concentration of circulating estrogens (free estradiol, estrone, and estriol). A predominance of superficial epithelial cells (the most mature type) indicates higher concentrations of circulating estrogens. Intermediate cells are moderately mature

questions.text: Cornification index or eosinophilic index indicates:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The vaginal epithelium is responsive to sex steroids, particularly estrogen, and undergoes predictable changes through the cycle in response to changes in blood concentrations of ovarian hormones. Rising levels of estrogen cause the vaginal epithelium to become "cornified" - the surface cells become large and flattened, with small or absent nuclei.

questions.text: Main source of testosterone in females is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Peripheral conversion of androstenedione. Explanation for Correct Answer (D): The primary source of testosterone in females is through the peripheral conversion of androstenedione, a precursor hormone that is produced by both the adrenal glands and ovaries. Androstenedione is converted into testosterone by various peripheral tissues, including the liver, adipose tissue, and muscle. This process is responsible for the majority of the testosterone found in females. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Adrenal gland: The adrenal glands do produce small amounts of testosterone, but they are not the primary source. The main role of the adrenal glands is to produce adrenal androgens like dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione, which can be converted into testosterone peripherally, but they do not directly produce significant quantities of testosterone. B. Ovary: The ovaries also produce testosterone, but they are not the main source in females. Testosterone is produced in smaller amounts in the ovaries compared to its peripheral conversion from androstenedione. C. Both a and b: While both the adrenal glands and ovaries contribute to the production of androgens and testosterone, the peripheral conversion of androstenedione is the primary source. Thus, this answer is not fully accurate as it overstates the contributions of the adrenal glands and ovaries compared to peripheral conversion.

choices.text: Often cured by delivery of a child
Pain usually appears on the first day of menstruation

questions.text: False statement regarding spasmodic dysmenorrhea is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Spasmodic dysmenorrhoea is another name for primary dysnenorrhoea. (i.e. no pelvic pathology is responsible for pain) Characteristics of spasmodic dysmenorrhoea Seen in adolescent girls Pain appears within 2 years of menarche Family history may be present Pain is spasmodic nature. It is located in lower abdomen and may radiate to back and medial aspect of thigh. Associated systemic discomfort seen Pain begins few hours before onset of menstruation and lasts for about 48 hours. Pain is often cured after child birth Management: NSAIDs or OCPs

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman gives a history of sharp pain in the lower abdomen for 2-3 days every month approximately 2 weeks before the menses. The most probable etiology for her pain is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mittelschmerz syndrome. Explanation for Correct Answer (D): Mittelschmerz syndrome refers to mid-cycle pain that occurs around ovulation, typically occurring 14 days before menstruation, which aligns with the timing described in the question. The pain is often sharp and localized to one side of the lower abdomen, reflecting the side of ovulation. This pain usually lasts for a few hours to a couple of days and is generally not associated with any other underlying pathology, making it the most probable diagnosis for this woman's symptoms. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Endometriosis: Endometriosis is a condition where tissue similar to the lining of the uterus grows outside of it, often causing chronic pelvic pain. However, the pain is typically more continuous and occurs throughout the menstrual cycle, not specifically 2-3 days before menses or tied to ovulation. The timing and nature of the pain described in the question are not characteristic of endometriosis. B. Dysmenorrhea: Dysmenorrhea refers to pain associated with menstruation, usually occurring just before or during the onset of menses. The pain described in the question happens 2-3 days before menses and is sharp and localized, which is more typical of ovulatory pain (Mittelschmerz) than menstrual cramps associated with dysmenorrhea. C. Pelvic tuberculosis: Pelvic tuberculosis can cause chronic pelvic pain, but it usually presents with more severe symptoms, often accompanied by other signs like weight loss, fever, and irregular menstrual cycles. The pain described in the question is too short-lived and has a specific timing related to ovulation, making pelvic tuberculosis less likely in this case.

questions.text: Precocious puberty may be seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hyperthyroidism. Explanation for Correct Answer (D): Hyperthyroidism typically does not cause precocious puberty. In fact, it is more commonly associated with delayed puberty or other endocrine disturbances rather than the early onset of puberty. Hyperthyroidism increases metabolic rate, which might lead to other symptoms such as weight loss, increased heart rate, and irritability, but it does not directly stimulate early sexual development or lead to precocious puberty. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Granulosa-cell tumour: Granulosa-cell tumors of the ovary can produce estrogen, leading to early onset of puberty in girls, particularly before the age of 8. This increased estrogen production can result in the development of secondary sexual characteristics, thus leading to precocious puberty. B. Head injury: Head injuries, particularly those involving the hypothalamus or pituitary gland, can disrupt the normal regulation of puberty, potentially leading to precocious puberty. This is known as central precocious puberty, where hormonal signals that trigger puberty are released prematurely due to brain injury. C. Corticosteroid intake: Corticosteroid use, especially in high doses or over a long period, can affect the endocrine system and lead to early puberty. Corticosteroids can sometimes stimulate the adrenal glands, contributing to changes in the body’s hormonal balance, which may cause precocious puberty in some cases.

questions.text: Precocious puberty associated with bony dysplasia and cafe au lait spots in skin is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Precocious puberty with bony dysplasia and cafe au lait spots points towards McCune-Albright syndrome as the diagnosis. McCune-Albright Syndrome is characterized by the classic triad of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia of bone, irregular cafe au lait spots on skin and GnRH independent sexual precocity The precocious puberty is the result of secretion of estrogen from functioning ovarian cysts. The cafe au lait spots are usually large, do not cross the midline and have irregular “coast of maine” margins. They are located on the same side as the bony lesion Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome is hypothalamic amenorrhea + mental retardation + polydactyl + retinitis pigmentosa. Frohlich Syndrome is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism + obesity + genital hypoplasia Both these are causes of delayed puberty and not precocious puberty

questions.text: What is the first sign of puberty in a girl?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thelarche. Explanation for Correct Answer (A): Thelarche, which is the development of breast tissue, is the first physical sign of puberty in girls. It typically occurs between the ages of 8 and 13 and is one of the earliest indicators of the onset of puberty. Thelarche marks the beginning of the hormonal changes that lead to further sexual maturation, such as the growth of pubic hair and menstruation. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: B. Menarche: Menarche, which is the first menstrual period, is a later event in puberty. It typically occurs about 2-3 years after the onset of thelarche. Therefore, menarche is not the first sign of puberty but rather one of the later stages of development. C. Adrenarche: Adrenarche refers to the increased secretion of adrenal androgens, which leads to the early development of pubic hair and other signs of sexual maturation. While it occurs around the same time as thelarche, it is not the first sign of puberty in girls, as thelarche typically occurs slightly earlier. D. Pubarche: Pubarche refers to the appearance of pubic hair, which generally follows thelarche and is part of the process of adrenarche. Pubarche happens after the onset of thelarche, so it is not the first sign of puberty.

questions.text: The secretion of FSH in a male is inhibited by negative feedback effect of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Inhibin secreted by Sertoli cells. Explanation for Correct Answer (A): In males, the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) is primarily regulated by a negative feedback mechanism involving inhibin. Inhibin is secreted by Sertoli cells, which are located in the seminiferous tubules of the testes. When inhibin levels increase, they act on the anterior pituitary to decrease the secretion of FSH, thus helping to regulate spermatogenesis and maintain the appropriate levels of FSH in the bloodstream. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: B. Inhibin secreted by Leydig cells: Leydig cells secrete testosterone, not inhibin. While testosterone also plays a role in the feedback regulation of FSH through negative feedback, Leydig cells do not secrete inhibin, and therefore, they cannot directly inhibit FSH secretion. C. Testosterone secreted by Sertoli cells: Sertoli cells are responsible for nurturing developing sperm, and while they do secrete some estrogen and other factors, they do not secrete testosterone. Testosterone, which is mainly secreted by Leydig cells, does play a role in feedback regulation, but it is not the direct cause of FSH inhibition by Sertoli cells. D. Testosterone secreted by Leydig cells: Testosterone secreted by Leydig cells does contribute to the negative feedback regulation of both LH and FSH levels. However, the direct inhibition of FSH secretion by the pituitary is primarily due to inhibin secreted by Sertoli cells, not testosterone. Testosterone's role is more focused on inhibiting LH secretion and maintaining the overall function of the testes.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl, complains of heavy periods since 2 months. O/E: wt 40 kg and BP 120/80 mm Hg. All of the following investigations are indicated, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Important causes of puberty menorrhagia are: HPO axis immaturity (anovulation) Bleeding disorders Endocrinological causes Hence TSH, platelet count and BT/CT are done S. estradiol levels are of no utility in the workup of this patient. Note: Always rule out bleeding disorder in patients of puberty menorrhagia.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman who has not started her menses since a vaginal delivery 1 year previously complicated by postpartum hemorrhage. She was unable to breast-feed her baby Which of the following single best direct mechanisms for amenorrhea
questions.solution: B. Sheehan syndrome is when the anterior pituitary suffers from hemorrhagic necrosis associated with postpartum hemorrhage. She is unable to breast-feed due to her inability to release prolactin from the anterior pituitary. This patient’s symptoms are unrelated to the ovaries and hypothalamus. This patient would be in a hypoestrogenic state due to the lack of gonadotropin stimulation. Treatment for this would be supplemental hormonal replacement

questions.text: Match the letters A,B,C,D with the hormones they represent in the menstrual cycle
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) LH and FSH peak before ovulation although the peak of LH is much bigger than peak of FSH LH peak is seen 12 hrs before ovulation while LH surge is seen 36 hrs before ovulation Estrogen peak is seen 12 hrs before ovulation and another smaller rise is seen after ovulation Progesterone synthesis begins before ovulation and peak levels are seen 8 days after ovulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a classic symptom of menopause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Visual changes. Explanation for Correct Answer (C): Visual changes are not considered a classic symptom of menopause. Menopause primarily affects the reproductive and endocrine systems, leading to symptoms like hot flashes, insomnia, and vaginal atrophy. While hormonal changes may indirectly impact vision (e.g., through dry eyes or changes in the lens), visual disturbances are not commonly associated with the onset of menopause. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Hot flashes: Hot flashes are one of the most common and classic symptoms of menopause. They occur due to fluctuations in estrogen levels, leading to sudden feelings of intense heat, often accompanied by sweating and flushing, especially during the night. B. Insomnia: Insomnia or sleep disturbances are frequently reported during menopause due to hormonal changes, particularly the decrease in estrogen levels, which can affect the regulation of sleep patterns and contribute to difficulties falling or staying asleep. D. Vaginal atrophy: Vaginal atrophy, which involves thinning and dryness of the vaginal walls, is another common symptom of menopause. It occurs as a result of reduced estrogen levels, leading to a decrease in vaginal lubrication and elasticity, which can cause discomfort or pain during intercourse.

questions.text: Which of these structures does NOT produce progesterone?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The endometrium does not produce progesterone. The corpus luteum produces progesterone to maintain the endometrium until the placenta takes over at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation. In the absence of fertilization, the corpus luteum degenerates, and the progesterone levels fall, so the endometrium is unable to be maintained, resulting in a menstruation. The follicle produces progesterone in response to the LH surge and results in ovulation. This follicle then becomes the corpus luteum after ovulation.

questions.text: Premenopausal peripheral conversion of estrogen precursors in the obese patient results in the formation of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In premenopausal adult women, most of the estrogen in the body is derived from ovarian secretion of estradiol, but a significant portion comes also from the extraglandular conversion of androstenedione to estrone. To a lesser extent, testosterone conversion to estradiol also contributes to the estrogen milieu. Muscle and adipose tissue are the major sites of aromatization. When there is an increase in fat cells, as in obese persons, estrogen levels will be higher, because adipose tissue exhibits a greater aromatization of androstenedione to estrone than does muscle.
